I can only hope that Gosling and Refn had a grand old time making Only God Forgives, because watching it sure is a bore.
Even though it's an improvement over the first RED, the film as a whole is just as disposable.
Wiig's shtick-heavy performance is just the tip of the iceberg when it comes to the problems afflicting this dire "comedy."

The Wolverine is good enough that I kept wishing it were better -- that there was another layer to the story or another wrinkle to a character's motivation or a truly spectacular set-piece that lent the proceedings some extra oomph.
Even when the jokes don't land, the sheer likability of the cast keeps the audience engaged.
If you want to see what capital-A Acting looks like, take a gander at Cate Blanchett in Woody Allen's latest feature.
We're pretty sure this is the last we'll ever see of the new Munster clan.
What's missing from The Butler aren't good performance, solid production values and an obvious respect for history -- it's the ability to make that history seem vital, to make it matter.
The first Kick-Ass wasn't a great movie, but it did have two great jokes driving it. With Kick-Ass 2, the joke is entirely on the audience.
One heck of a generic genre piece.
movie_title: The Mortal Instruments: City of Bones (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A rewarding experience, even if it fails to completely sweep you off your feet.
It all pays off in a truly powerful closing scene that features some of the best screen acting Hanks has ever done.
I'm So Excited has more than enough characters and storylines to fill its confined space. What the movie lacks, however, are belly laughs, hearty guffaws or even mild chuckles.
The fact that it was shot on location is the most interesting thing about this curiosity, which otherwise isn't inventive or innovative enough to enter the canon of the truly great cult classics.
A Vegas-set dramedy that begins as a spikey comedy only to evolve into precisely the kind of banal, self-improvement seminar that one of Cody's edgy heroines would snark endlessly through.

As if we needed one, Philomena gives us all yet another reason to praise Judi Dench, the Grand Dame of contemporary British cinema and an actress capable of elevating even the most predictable material.
A spirited romp through a traditional Disney princess narrative that ultimately tweaks the formula in ways that make it exciting and new.
It's in moments like that that Black Nativity really sings; the rest of the time it operates at a familiar hum.
If somebody had to remake Oldboy, I'm glad it was Spike Lee.

It's the most incongruous (and enjoyably so) good guy/bad guy pairing since Philip Seymour Hoffman threatened to make Tom Cruise's girlfriend bleed and cry and call out his name in Mission: Impossible III.
There's ultimately too much chaos and not enough control in Chadwick's presentation of Mandela's decades-spanning history.
Yet another home run for a pair of filmmakers who have proven incapable of striking a false note for four movies now.
A movie that sets out to be the antidote to glossy revenge pictures, but becomes that very thing.
Vaughn stumbles through the movie looking perpetually annoyed, as if he's just been woken up from a nap.
It's a film about the process of creativity, one that shows just how closely art and science are often intertwined.

In its reliance on sloganeering in place of substantive debate, The Unbelievers winds up being almost as insular as any dogmatic religious group. Instead of opening viewers' minds, it's just preaching to the choir.
As a Middle-earth softie, The Desolation of Smaug mostly provides what I've been hoping to get out of Jackson's second tour-of-duty in Tolkien land.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: It's a messy movie, yes, but that complements the messy personalities at its center.
As much as the script strains to connect Travers' past with her present, Saving Mr. Banks instead resembles two very different movies shoved together.
Seeing The Sound of Music on DVD minus the live element (and its driving, hate watch-fueled Twitter traffic) makes it seem like an even bigger mess.
Flabby though it may be at times, this sequel delivers a steady stream of laughs and, more importantly, doesn't diminish our goodwill for this bunch of idiots.
I really can't say enough about how vividly the filmmaker and his creative team render this World of Tomorrow.
At three hours long, The Wolf of Wall Street also stands as a monument to the characters' flair for excess.
Nuclear Nation's anti-nuclear stance is very clear, but it admirably wants viewers to understand its argument instead of shouting it at them.
This new creative team doesn't just repeat the previous film or the book... they substantially improve upon both.

Having picked such an intriguing environment to depict onscreen, it's more than a little disappointing that Nashef then settles for such a routine storyline, one that's flatly told and not all that funny to boot.
A deceptively low-key road movie that carries some real comedic and dramatic bite.
In his typically visceral way, McQueen rips the scab off a wound that may never fully heal and dares us to look away.
Condon doesn't trust the story -- or history itself -- to be interesting enough on its own terms.
I was completely absorbed throughout All is Lost and appreciated the skill with which Chandor brought his very specific vision to life.
This interpretation does a nice job exploring the moral complexity of King's revenge premise... at least until Carrie is required by the plot to unleash hell.
Despite solid performances and handsome production values, Kill Your Darlings ends up feeling like a 100-minute preamble to the real story of the Beat Generation.
A rushed, chaotic and almost incoherent recap of the backstory behind the Lower East Side's iconic (and now defunct) punk music club.
All but certain to irritate general audiences and crater at the box office, The Counselor is nevertheless perversely fascinating -- half misfire and half inspired.
An absorbing, relatable story that also achieves an intimacy and raw emotional power.
Suffers from the same too-muchness of Love Actually and almost-instantaneous forgettability of Pirate Radio.
Even the committed efforts of these veteran actors can't completely distract from the movie's reliance on hoary clichés and predictable jokes.
McConaughey delivers a fine performance in Dallas Buyers Club, but it's less impressive when you realize that the entire movie has been rigged in his favor.
In its best moments, the film offers the mix of impressive spectacle and resonant substance that you always hope for when headed into the latest sci-fi blockbuster.

Because HBO will basically let him do whatever he wants, Larry David passed up making another season of Curb Your Enthusiasm to instead write and star in this semi-improvised feature that has an A-list cast and C-list material.
Andrew Cohn and Davy Rothbart's debut documentary feature is an evocative portrait of a small town in crisis. Too bad the basketball stuff keeps getting in the way.
It's a good thing that Taylor and the cast have such a firm grasp on the mirco details, because on a macro-level, The Dark World just barely hangs together.
It's all a little overwrought to be honest, with Macdonald unable to effectively modulate the movie's mood swings.
A smart, involving movie that effectively tackles real-world issues within the context of a well-plotted narrative.
The running time may be intimidating, but At Berkeley absolutely belongs on the short list of the year's finest documentaries.
If The Wind Rises doesn't soar to the heights of the director's finest works, it is a deeply felt and visually ravishing goodbye from one of the undisputed masters of modern animation.
Though an evocative portrait of a particular place, Juan Manuel Echavarría's slender documentary never feels as though it's telling the whole story.
It's a well-executed survival story, but it misses the chance to amount to anything more.
The revamped vampire mythology put forth in Byzantium is much more fascinating than the actual story the movie sets out to tell.
The Heat may be more of the same buddy cop stuff, but the stars lend it extra punch where it counts.
The movie version completely drains the narrative of whatever charm or intrigue might have existed on the page, leaving behind a dry, withered husk.
Unable to fall back on his default strongman setting, Johnson is more human than we've seen him before.
Singer throws expensive-looking set piece after expensive-looking set piece at the screen and none of it sticks.
Thanks to Park's endless creativity behind the camera, it's impossible to look away from Stoker, even when what's happening on the screen is truly risible.
This is, at heart, a melodrama cloaked in action movie clothing.
Taken purely on its own terms, Oz the Great and Powerful is a serviceable family blockbuster.
The Girl is still more "good for you" than "good," but at least it supplements its feature-length lecture with a pair of good performances and a decent payoff.
Watching Don't Stop Believin' one always gets the sense that there's a larger story that Diaz can't -- or simply doesn't want to -- tell.
That this utterly disposable, entirely generic piece of action movie mayhem is allowed to advertise itself under the Die Hard banner is a travesty.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: It's like of one of those deadly Saturday Night Live sketches where everyone involved clearly knows it isn't working, but they're forced to go through the motions anyway simply to avoid dead air.
A highly stylized art film that brutally (and, at times, brilliantly) sends up a society and (pop) culture that enables and enhances all the things it claims to bemoan.
I'm not quite sure why Stewart felt compelled to make this movie, but to her credit I guess, she commits to the story she's telling, as lurid, unpleasant and ultimately pointless as it may be.
Even if the movie itself isn't any fun, spotting all of its blatant mistakes and Ed Wood-ian budgetary shortfalls definitely is.
It's mostly harmless, but also pretty lifeless.
While Huard is an appealing performer the pace of the storytelling and the comedy is too languid and pokey.
Even mindless action has to have a baseline amount of mental energy behind it.
A kooky comedy in which a spirited cast is almost suffocated by too-aggressive direction.
Overall, Blancanievesis a minor achievement in the annals of Snow White re-tellings, but not an insignificant one.
Save for one genuinely exciting stretch that begins roughly a half-hour in, the bulk of the film is dull and derivative.
What's striking is that even though the directors have been given complete freedom, so many of the shorts wind up being the same.
Even when Burns's script falters, Soderbergh's direction remains laser-precise.

Watching Bullet to the Head you're acutely aware of how stupid and pointless the whole enterprise, yet at the same time the movie successfully delivers a steady stream of short, sharp shocks to your system that keep you engaged.
Watching Reacher piece this puzzle together, my overarching feeling was "Who cares?" rather than "Who dunnit?"
Hooper and the cast do get at the beating heart of the play and ultimately provide the kind of cathartic experience that continues to make the [musical] a favorite.
[The film] often feels stuck in second gear dramatically, remaining watchable without ever becoming truly compelling.
Chase makes these familiar scenarios feel vital and fresh, thanks to a terrific eye for detail, a general avoidance of on-the-nose social commentary and an incredible soundtrack.
Django Unchained is good -- I'd even go so far as to say very good -- but with a bit more care, it could have been as great as the movie Tarantino has been describing in interviews.
Damon and Krasinski have the makings of a decent writing team, but their next script would benefit from a few more revisions.
A worthwhile appendix to the West Memphis Three case.
The film's power stems from the way Haneke avoids milking the viewer's sympathy.
If 56 Up is something of a pleasant bore while you're watching it, it gains more resonance when you think about it as the calm before the approaching storm.
An intriguing depiction of urban gentrification in action, marred somewhat by an unnecessary dip into the first person.
The movie doesn't much build to a climax as accidentally stumble upon it on the way to the closing credits.
Struck By Lightning possesses a jarring mixture of tones, with moments of dark comedy sitting somewhat uneasily alongside scenes of quiet domestic drama.
Quartet is ultimately too thinly conceived, lacking a compelling dramatic throughline.
The middle section of the film just drags on and on, as Mama lurks about the house popping out an inopportune moments while Muschietti stalls for time.
A solid, if unexceptional, urban crime yarn.
While Jee-woon has displayed a great deal of visual flair in his South Korean features, his work here proves disappointingly straightforward and impersonal.
Statham allows himself to be goofy on occasion as well, which is why this ranks as one of his most enjoyable performances to date.
Not only did Warm Bodies fail to convince me of its central conceit, but the movie's general depiction of zombie life is shoddy, inconsistent and often downright dumb.
Not since Pacino squared off against Robert De Niro in Righteous Kill has a single movie so thoroughly blasphemed a set of Acting Gods.
Make no mistake, The Host is a bad movie, but it's the kind of bad movie that's almost compulsively watchable if only to see how much worse it could possibly get.
White House Down is as much a comic book fantasy as something like The Avengers.
This entire saga climaxes in an a moment of catharsis that feels remarkably pat and simplistic.
Boyle gets Trance off to his usual strong start, but it's Dawson who keeps the film afloat in its darkest (second) hour.
Compared to the wackadoo ramblings of The Happening or the stark-raving silliness of Lady in the Water, this film is a more generic failure.
The father/son tension between Frank and Joe is also effectively handled, with Offerman in particular striking notes that skirt around the typical coming-of-age, daddy-just-doesn't-get-me clichés.
The movie is sure-footed in its storytelling, right up to its appropriately open-ended conclusion.
The premise is the only interesting thing about The Purge, which very quickly devolves into a poorly-staged, narratively-challenged home invasion picture.
Rapture-Palooza assembles a reliable cast of comics and then proceeds to saddle them with truly middling material.
Clever for a little while, but turns irritating halfway through.
A modest pleasure that greatly benefits from Weixler's charismatic presence.
It's a 50/50 split as two of the shorts are great and two... well, not so much.
The Fast and the Furious franchise's gradual transformation from action movie serial to full-blown TV soap opera (with occasional car chases) is at last complete.
Tiger Eyes retains some of the seriousness and respect for character that distinguishes Blume's YA books. What it lacks, however, is her strong authorial voice.
[It's] more interested in making you smile than making you think. And it mostly accomplishes that modest goal, thanks to the witty music and charmingly low-fi production values.
I had a grand old time at this apocalypse, where 75-80% of the jokes land and the cast's eager-to-please energy, mostly carry you through the gags that fall short.
This is the first time where the director has allowed herself to be so openly contemptuous of the people in her own movie and that judgmental air suffocates The Bling Ring.
Man of Steel keeps Superman -- and the aspirational spirit he represents -- grounded and it's a less heroic movie for it.
World War Z may be a Frankenstein's monster of a movie, but it crackles with just enough electricity to keep the story moving forward and take the audience along for the ride.
Monsters University takes characters and plugs them into a sitcom-ready scenario that could serve as a backdoor pilot to a Disney Channel series.
Should Wood decide to indulge his manic side again, here's hoping he picks a better vehicle than Maniac.
A Hijacking accomplishes a tricky task, generating tension through talk rather than action.
It's a delight for Whedonites, but -- I'm sorry to say -- a rather mediocre production of Shakespeare.

No matter how long the gap between movies has been or how completely the characters' lives have changed, when Jesse and Celine turn to each other and start one of their famously epic conversations, it feels like no time has passed at all.
Turning this installment into The Hangover III: The Search for Chow illustrates how starved for ideas the filmmakers are.

As you can probably tell, I found the message behind Phil Spector pretty laughable. As drama, it's not particularly convincing either, even with Mamet's rat-a-tat-tat flair for dialogue mostly intact.
A small-scale, working-class character study that's never quite as nuanced and dramatic as it aspires to be.
[It] takes a crucial piece of sports and social history and treats it with kid gloves, substituting Hollywood gloss for real-world grit.
You already have to be a fan of Malick to want to look past the movie's somewhat bland surface. But if you do, you might experience some of the wonder promised by the title.
It's not laugh-out-loud hysterical, but the ensemble -- Cross and the always-amusing Hayes in particular -- establishes a just-zany-enough rapport that's enjoyable rather than irritating.
As a director, Kosinski is a great production designer. But as a dramatist? Not so much.
Cusack's glum visage immediately lays a wet blanket over Danish director Kasper Barfoed's English-language debut and keeps it firmly in place until the final fade-out.
For the first half, Bay is completely dialed into this material, his frat boy sense of humor and overblown visual sensibility complimenting the story and setting.
The second installment in a planned martial-arts trilogy mixes broad comedy and cartoonish action that will appeal to the genre's fans, though crossover potential seems limited.
For half the movie, Black challenges what audiences have come to expect from comic book movies and Marvel movies in particular. But then in the other half, he falls back on the same-old same-old.
Ultimately, Unmade in China is ultimately less about the experience of making a movie in China than it is a chronicle of one director's wounded ego.
The pleasure of the film doesn't lie in the plot; it's all about the sultry, horror-tinged mood that Cassavetes manufactures.
In the end -- for better and for worse -- this is very much Baz Luhrmann's Great Gatsby, a movie that honors the source material, but stays truer to its own creator's vision.
Aftershock's best attribute is the disregard it shows for the safety of its central "heroes" who perish in brutal and generally unexpected ways.
How Sweet It Is may be sweet in spirit, but as a movie it isn't so, you know, sweet.
Syrup imagines itself to be bolder and funnier than it actually is.
Into Darkness repeatedly and unapologetically sacrifices science-fiction thoughtfulness on the altar of blockbuster "Wow."
Although Erased goes through the motions of its various spy games efficiently enough, you never completely forget that you're watching an imitation of far better movies.

A strained attempt to translate the comic punch of Alexander Payne's brilliant send-up of high-school politics, Election, into the realm of an even more tension-fraught extracurricular activity: drama club.
McGehee and Siegel -- as well as the adult cast -- are to be commended for keeping the film's depiction of marital strife from falling into melodrama and goopy sentimentality.
No one saw Raimi's Evil Dead coming three decades ago and were unprepared for what it had to offer. This Evil Dead delivers what you expect... and it's the weaker for it.
Too much money was spent on this version of the legend of the 47 Ronin for it to be classified as a wholly inept failure. What it does represent, though, is a failure of imagination.
Those hoping for comic fireworks to erupt between the meeting of these grumpy old men will be disappointed.
Honestly, the only meaning I took away from The Secret Life of Walter Mitty is that it makes Simple Jack look like Citizen Kane.
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Thoughtful but uneven attempt to recast a traditional zombie narrative as an Abraham and Isaac metaphor.
Cox must have seen something in this screenplay that encouraged her to film it, but whatever that critical element was, it's not apparent in the finished product.
A father and daughter hit the road to repair their relationship, but end up trying the audience's patience.
It's questionable whether Dark Star will create new fans of Giger's work, but for his admirers it at least provides a small window into his everyday world.
Tomorrowland has the ragged, jagged feel of a tale that was reworked countless times on the page, during production and in the editing room.
The Nightmare probes its participants' minds without finding anything particularly revealing or, ultimately, that frightening.
Offers solid fight sequences, but little else.
Like the franchise it's clearly inspired by-the Step Up series-ABCD 2 tricks out simple messages with spectacular dance sequences.
The film achieves a level of proficient mediocrity early on and hovers there for the rest of its slender running time.
A movie that seems to have been made out of obligation rather than desire.
The narrative is leaden and lumpy in a way that suggests prolonged script-tinkering.
The heavily hyped marriage between Amy Schumer and Judd Apatow doesn't always result in comedy bliss, but it does frequently provide the gift of belly laughs.
For anyone over the age of 10, this videogame-derived disaster movie will just be a disaster.
Despite likeable performances by the young cast and some resonant moments, this gauzy teen drama is, sadly, paper-thin.
[After an interesting first half, Extinction] consumes its own brains and becomes another mindless creature feature.
[The directors] don't feel the compulsion to [...] expand on any of the information that was likely handed directly to them by the company's public-relations team.
Understandably if disappointingly leery of asking too many difficult questions about [Farley's] life and death.
May tread familiar territory, but at least it does so with great empathy and thoughtfulness.
movie_title: The Diary Of A Teenage Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: What lasting resonance Amy does achieve has less to do with the story that Kapadia assembles and more with the real-life moments he uses as building blocks.
Unfriended proves that you absolutely can make a movie that unfolds entirely on a computer. The question it doesn't answer is why you'd want to.
Beautifully crafted, but empty at its core.
Will Ferrell and Kevin Hart join forces for a fitfully amusing but problematically conceived modern-day version of Trading Places.
Little Accidents strikes the mournful tone of grand tragedy, but the dramatic notes fall flat.
Seriously, if a movie ever deserved a "Buyer Beware" rating, it's Vice-the mash-up of Westworld and Blade Runner that nobody wanted or needed.
Hart himself is his usual affable, amusing self, but if he's set on becoming a comic actor-as opposed to a pure comic-he has to start prioritizing the scripts over the jokes.
A glum, pedestrian attempt at a "real world" musical that ultimately feels as artificial as a ritzy Broadway show.
Strange Magic is an effective argument against the predominance of computer animation as the current industry standard.
A boldly, baldly opportunistic attempt to aid in the group's return to mainstream relevance.
movie_title: Backstreet Boys: Show 'Em What You're Made Of (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Although moments of playful wit abound throughout, Sponge Out of Water is often so nosily frenetic, it verges on being assaultive.
movie_title: The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Jupiter Ascending routinely seems flummoxed by its own mythology and characters.
Flat and formless in execution.
Only fans of the first movie will want to make time for this occasionally inspired, mostly tedious follow-up.
To borrow a lesson from Stephen Colbert, instead of accepting Kung Fu Elliot as truth, you might be better off approaching it as an illustration of "truthiness."
Comedy plus tragedy equals boredom in Adam Carolla's crowdfunded star vehicle.
There are ordinary homages and then there are high-quality cinematic mix tapes like It Follows.
For a movie that has no reason to exist beyond maximizing Disney's back catalogue, Kenneth Branagh's live action Cinderella is an entirely enjoyable piece of fairy tale theater.
The musicians' memories, coupled with the murderers' row of killer tunes that play on the soundtrack, carry you along and recreate a period in the music industry that's long since vanished.
The Hunting Ground directly and, at times, bluntly argues its case, appealing directly to the audiences' sense of moral outrage.
So deprived of laughs (not to mention brains), it makes Meet the Spartans and Vampires Suck look like Airplane! or Hot Shots.
Tracers gifts the world with the mash-up of Oliver Twist and parkour that it never knew it needed, and will justifiably ignore.
The lack of any memorable story elements or overall narrative drive might not be so pronounced if this post-apocalyptic future were even halfway interesting.
A smorgasbord of a musical biopic in which the strength of the individual parts compensates for the flaws of the whole.
Película starts to feel repetitious and hermetically sealed, a prolonged joke that's unsustainable precisely because it's targeted at such an ultra-specific audience.
[Christian Cantamessa has] the eye of a promising director-now he just needs a better script.
A sequel that has no reason to exist is also a movie that has no reason to be seen.
Isao Takahata's 1991 animated feature belatedly arrives on U.S. screens and thankfully hasn't aged a day.
The night is dark and not so full of terrors in "Game of Thrones" star Natalie Dormer's first foray into C-grade J-horror.
Not out there enough to work as gonzo period comedy, and certainly not trenchant enough to succeed as satire, Moonwalkers is an imitation of a real movie.
With one notable exception, the quality of this horror anthology mostly heads in one direction: south.
Early on, Deadpool teases audiences that it's going to lead a comedy-laced comic-book movie revolution, but it ends up joining the superhero establishment.
While it builds to an intriguing thematic question, the dramatic situation at the heart of Tobias Lindholm's war-themed procedural is a little too open-and-shut.
[An] endearingly goofy gloss on the Old World fantasy spectacles of yesteryear.
A sequel in third act only, 10 Cloverfield Lane successfully switches out monster-movie mayhem for chamber-room chills.
The odd-couple comedy duo of Ferrell & Wahlberg enlivens this mostly tedious comedy, which has hints of a darker, more interesting film lurking underneath.
Although there's technically one more film to go in the four-part Divergent Series, this third installment reveals a franchise already on its last legs.
A contemporary Blair Witch Project knock-off that feels significantly more dated than the film it's inspired by.
More like Headache-Inducing Henry.
Karyn Kusama's quietly chilling direction enlivens a somewhat plodding housebound thriller.
Jeremy Saulnier's wickedly entertaining follow-up to Blue Ruin makes a big impression by staying small.
Errol Morris appears to serve as the inspiration for Nicolas Steiner's documentary, which possesses some of that director's artistry but lacks his inquisitive spirit.
Keanu is proof positive that Key & Peele are one of the great contemporary comedy duos, even if the feature surrounding them is little more than a shaggy-cat story.
The Marvel blockbuster machine keeps on trucking with a double-sized new issue of Captain America that packs enough punch to distract from its grinding plot mechanics.
The English-language debut of Greek director Yorgos Lanthimos is built on a terrific premise, but some cracks appear in the foundation by the final act.
Zack Snyder's wearying superhero opus may be slugged "Dawn of Justice," but it's the twilight of any hope that the filmmaker will find the fun in the DC Universe.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: If [Concussion] serves any purpose at all, it's as a reminder that Will Smith is an A-grade movie star, even in C-grade material.
Eight too often feels wearying, a film of modest ambition made by a director with unlimited resources.
Strives to unite old and new generations of Star Wars fans and mostly succeeds.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A standout star turn from Elisabeth Moss enlivens and deepens Alex Ross Perry's extended Roman Polanski homage.
Like our good neighbor to the north, this first-person documentary is genial, amusing and a little bit dull.
Cooties struggles to fill 90 minutes with a premise that could support, at most, five minutes of great content.
Robert De Niro soars in Nancy Meyers' latest-too bad the movie itself only intermittently achieves liftoff.
A diverting animated sequel that, believe it or not, boasts one of Adam Sandler's most affecting performances.
Within the guise of a rarefied ode to silent movies, Maddin may have made his most commercial film.
Oh, what short form sci-fi master Ray Bradbury would have made of this overlong short story!
War is (a beautiful) hell in Cary Joji Fukunaga's disconcertingly picturesque combat film.
While there may be some slight stiffness in the storytelling joints, Guillermo del Toro's Gothic love story is a visually ravishing delight.
A sweet, well-meaning confection that doesn't provide a lot of genre nourishment.
Despite working from extraordinary subject matter-Edgar Allan Poe's various tales of the macabre-too many entries in this animated anthology are disappointingly ordinary.
One of the most invigorating portraits of democracy in action to come along in recent memory.
More a doodle than a fully formed documentary, this chronicle of a modern-day musical maestro nevertheless dances to an intriguing tune.
[A] slick, efficient and utterly banal piece of global cinema product.
M. Night Shyamalan's first foray into found-footage territory conjures up a few scares, but otherwise operates on autopilot.
A warm-hearted, if somewhat superficial, exploration of how great music crosses borders, composed in the key of Buena Vista Social Club.
The reigning YA franchise champ laces up for one final round, and (mostly) manages to go out on top.
Gentle to a fault, this quiet adaptation of the Finnish comic strip will likely only delight the Moomin faithful.
Although the style of László Nemes' Holocaust drama at times threatens to overwhelm the substance, the movie has a cumulative power that's difficult to shake.
A perceptive, if sometimes heavy-handed, drama about love and marriage.
It's the filmmakers' own lack of imagination that will likely doom this would-be franchise to an early grave.
movie_title: The Woman in Black 2 Angel of Death (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Jolie has clearly demonstrated she has the chops to shoot a good movie; her next challenge is to make a personal one.
An impassioned lead performance and timely parallels to contemporary social issues enliven and elevate this otherwise somewhat routine biopic.

What's special about this film is that, while it bears all the hallmarks of his by-now entirely too familiar style, it also finds him acknowledging the limitations of that style when it butts up against a certain measure of reality

Even though I enjoyed watching an older Mars reacquaint herself with Neptune, no small amount of disappointment set in as I realized Thomas was guiding the proceedings to an ending that would reinforce the series' status quo.

Bad Words gets squishy and sentimental as it approaches its endgame, operating on the mistaken assumption that it needs to explain its anti-hero's pathology and, thus, let him off the hook for his behavior.
Broadbent attacks the part with gusto, though, allowing the audience to understand Nick without forcing them to necessarily find him sympathetic.
Though it has interesting passages, overall Teenage feels like a trailer for the yet-to-be-completed main feature.
This slender, but sweet buddy comedy boasts lovely 2D animation, a great story and, best of all, a distinctly original world that keeps revealing new surprises.
It's a comedy that OD's on its own smug sense of entitlement.

Beneath the grandstanding, the film is a provocative, nuanced and even empathetic account of one woman's attempts to understand and perhaps eventually reconcile the mechanical and emotional factors that are bound up in sex.
Forget Rise of an Empire -- the movie really should have been slugged More of the Same.
Watching Devos slip in and out of Alix's various "characters" is one of the major pleasures of an otherwise modestly enjoyable film.
Though it has its interesting sections, this stilted documentary is more suited to a museum archive than a theatrical venue.

It brings me no great pleasure to report that the The Raid 2 is to The Raid as Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen was to the first Transformers: it's longer, flashier and bloated well past the point of tedium.
Too bad the film itself is a mediocre monument to a major historical figure.
Where Aronofsky's particular genius does come into play is in the first two acts of the film, where he creates a Biblical landscape that's unique and vibrant.
In the Blood director John Stockwell places Carano squarely center-stage and then abandons her there, allowing her to wilt in the spotlight's harsh glare.
And while it lacks the formal innovation of [von Trier's earlier] films...it's carried along by Gainsbourg's impassioned performance
...a mostly bland but very kid-friendly Spider-Man clone.
Sluggish morality-play-cum-horror movie that wastes much of its shock value on an impenetrable mythology.
Divergent is so busy setting the stage for what's to come, it forgets to show why what's happening now matters, too.
The real mystery here is how first-time director David Grovic was able to recruit a fairly experienced cast for what is, on the page, a distinctly amateur effort.
The Lunchbox's combination of well-drawn characters, thoughtful storytelling and vividly-realized setting makes it an easy recommendation for quality-starved moviegoers.
It may be too on-the-nose to say that Non-Stop doesn't stick the landing, but the speed at which the movie turns from pleasantly diverting to semi-disastrous botch is genuinely disheartening.
Clearly calculated to win Oscars, August: Osage County instead feels more worthy of a Razzie or two.
If you're looking for a cure to the common English period prestige picture, Ralph Fiennes's The Invisible Woman fits the bill nicely.
This is the first Ryan adventure that isn't directly based on a Clancy novel and perhaps that explains why it works as well as it does... at least until it doesn't.
Though it's claiming to be a comedy, the Ice Cube/Kevin Hart team-up Ride Along isn't actually funny. At all.
This distillation of 200 hours' worth of home movies probably means a lot for the family at its center, but less for those of us in the audience.
An agreeable way to kill 80 minutes.
Though it'll be confined to the art house circuit, Stranger By the Lake actually has all the ingredients of a mainstream, page-turning summer beach read.
That Nathan is able to cover so much ground in a mere 76 minutes makes 12 O'Clock Boys all the more remarkable and essential.
I'd like to think that one day, Reitman will be able to look back at this film and laugh at his mistakes and miscalculations. For now, we'll just have to do the laughing for him.
This tedious, originality-starved run through familiar rom-com tropes is basically one long awkward moment.
A nobly-intentioned feature that lacks the discipline and focus to unite its disparate elements into an effective whole.
In the guise of a rambunctious animated comedy, the duo have actually delivered a thoughtful and even moving treatise on the power of imagination and the magic of uninhibited creativity.
Johnson and Kazan quickly establish a chemistry that's cute-quirky rather than annoying-quirky.
This RoboCop is an assembly-line product where even the social commentary arrives pre-packaged.
For all its teasingly provocative set-up, it ultimately reveals itself to be pretty vanilla.
The core of the film -- the relationship between Amy and Rat -- clicks in a very real, very entertaining way.
The same glossy, generic pap that passes for big-screen romance these days.
About Last Night itself stands little chance of leaving a lasting impression, but it may have gifted us with birth of a new comedy team.
Timely subject matter and a compelling story ultimately win over uneven performances.
An effective regional crime drama in the key of Jeff Nichols, but lacking his emotional and thematic complexity.
Had it been posted to YouTube rather than released in theatres, Friended to Death would have deservedly earned a surplus of "I dislike this" votes.
Believe it or not, underneath this raucous, riotous squares-vs.-slobs comedy lies a thoughtful character study.

Director Edwards holds back on unleashing the full might of his titans until the very end, and while the finale is appropriately rousing, it makes the preceding set-pieces play more like teasers than complete scenes.
Kink may ultimately be too slight to rank as a great documentary, but it does suggest the arrival of a great documentary filmmaker.
Neither significantly better nor worse than its predecessor, the belated Sin City sequel is more of a repeat, rather than a continuation, of the original.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A Wes Anderson facsimile that only serves to make you treasure the real thing all the more.
The exotic scenery simply isn't enough to make Finding Fanny a smooth ride.
It's pure shock-jock sensationalism, with the creative forces behind the movie throwing crap at the wall to see what sticks. That explains why the finished product is such a stinker.
Suffice it to say, the final set-piece encapsulates Tusk in a nutshell: It's strange, silly and difficult to look away from.
Intended as the portrait of an artist as a young man, the music doc Time is Illmatic is actually more interesting as a look back at the place and time that created him.
Stephen King adapts one of his own stories to the screen, but the finished product misses one crucial element: his voice.
Virtuosic camerawork and a stellar ensemble of actors more than make up for the occasional moment of portentous twaddle in Alejandro G. Inarritu's latest - and maybe his best - film.

So despite all that ambition and craft on display, why does the movie feel like such a stiff? That's largely because Paltrow's attention is so focused on big-picture details he takes his eyes off what's happening in the foreground with his characters.
One of the laziest, least frightening mainstream horror movies in recent memory.
If The ABCs of Death 2 seems like a slight improvement over its predecessor, that's simply due to the fact that it achieves a more consistent level of mediocrity.
[National Gallery] acknowledges the timelessness of great art while also outlining the hard work and harder choices required to make that timelessness possible.
Fueled by a knowing sense of humor and an eye for colorful spectacle, Big Hero 6 is fine, if sometimes too frenetic, family entertainment
[Wolves] is a bland bore, with few memorable character wrinkles or filmmaking flourishes to offset its cheap production values and second-rate story.
The majority of the films possess premises that are about as interesting as the execution...which is to say, not very.
The director's striking choice not to showcase sequences from Miyazaki's filmography underlines her subject's general disinterest in being deified as an icon.
movie_title: The Kingdom of Dreams and Madness (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Inherent Vice is confounding, challenging and consistently unique.
Up until now, Jackson's movies have fired up my imagination -- this one seems intent on shutting it down.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Taken on its own terms, though, it's a pleasant trifle aided immeasurably by a setting that's just as sumptuous (if not more so) than any of the rustic Italian meals the stars chow down on.
There's a high degree of insularity to the world Apatow presents onscreen.
With Jon, rather than Frank, as the film's focal point, 'Frank' flails about trying to establish a consistent rhythm, but mostly ends up striking false notes.
Joe Swanberg's latest feature is a collection of strong individual scenes and performances that never quite finds its statement of purpose.
Great performances keep this extended homage to seedy '80s thrillers walking the straight and narrow.
Even with its various stumbles and shortcomings, Days of Future Past provides consistently earnest and entertaining comic book movie spectacle
Despite strong work by Melanie Lynskey and Zachary Knighton, this so-called dark comedy is a big disappointment.
Seth MacFarlane's scattershot love letter to Blazing Saddles hits the comic bull's eye when it counts, but also has its fair share of misfires.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Gillian Robespierre's debut feature is a provocative, amusing comedy -- provided you cotton to the main character.
It may be just a feature-length commercial masquerading as a music documentary, but Under the Electric Sky at least sells its product well.
This sturdy sci-fi drama admirably poses some big questions, but doesn't possess the dramatic firepower to answer them effectively.
Mike Myers' relentlessly flattering profile of Hollywood manager and mensch Shep Gordon feels like it's not always telling the whole story.
movie_title: Supermensch: The Legend of Shep Gordon (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The Signal does boast some good ideas and effective moments, but for the most part its ambitions and execution of those ambitions are on different wavelengths.
Why fix what isn't broken? 22 Jump Street is, for a very specific reason, the exact same movie as its predecessor, and for once that isn't a criticism.
A witless, listless Bollywood comedy that feels every minute of its two-and-a-half-hour runtime.
David Wain does the world a solid by giving glossy romantic comedies the Wet Hot American Summer treatment.
If Rise of the Planet of the Apes successfully restarted the dormant Apes franchise, the superior Dawn indicates the grand saga this new iteration might become.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: There's a hollowness to this remake where its heart should be.
Believe the hype: Richard Linklater's decade-in-the-making epic is a remarkable achievement.
The unlikely team-up of rapper/businessman Jay Z and filmmaker Ron Howard doesn't result in odd-couple fireworks. Try familiar yawns instead.
You'd have to be a real nob to glean anything substantial from this superficial, haphazardly structured primer on videogame history.
Action-oriented animated sequel that, in blockbuster fashion, offers well-choreographed set-pieces in place of an interesting story and characters.
Purge: Anarchy still isn't a great movie, but in its strongest moments it channels some of the blunt-force trauma of vintage exploitation cinema.
Guardians of the Galaxy may be constructed as an action spectacle first and foremost, but it also features some of the strongest character work yet glimpsed in a Marvel Studios production.
The tsunami sequence is so well-executed, nothing else in the movie really comes close to matching it in terms of intensity.
Michel Gondry gets back to his low-budget roots and rediscovers his formidable formal playfulness in the process.
Meanders merrily along for 95 pain-free (and, honestly, mostly laugh-free) minutes before arriving at its entirely predictable destination.
The alien invader storyline often feels as though its happening in a completely different universe than the small-town story of friendship and first love
There's an interesting conceit at the core of Green Lantern, the otherwise overstuffed and clumsy superhero outing starring DC Comics' ring-wielding interstellar cop.
One tedious slog of a movie.
A Better Life is noble to the very end and that ends up being its undoing.
The behind-the-scenes stuff is just as hilarious as what we see of the on-stage material.
The one element of Bad Teacher that's consistently strong throughout is Diaz's ferocious star turn.
The sequel zooms along quickly enough, but its attempts at humor are often stale and forced and there's a distinct lack of emotion to the proceedings.
Dark of the Moon feels like less of a continuation of Revenge of the Fallen than a glorified repeat.
James Marsh spins another gripping, if occasionally superficial, true-life yarn in his follow-up to the Oscar-winning doc Man on Wire.
in its pleasantly low-key way, this is as inconsequential and instantly forgettable a movie as a bombastic blockbuster like Transformers: Dark of the Moon.
A ragtag R-rated comedy that ekes out just enough big laughs to make it worth your time.
Clunky writing and flat-footed direction derail this initially intriguing exploration into both the power and limits of belief.
While the movie doesn't offer any new insights into the era, it is a trip to see the home movies they shot on the road and hear them reminisce about their experiences.
The film takes advantage of its striking setting, but unfortunately the characters at its center gradually reveal themselves to be less interesting than they initially appear.
A solid, respectable genre piece that should play extra well when watched late one night in your own one or two-bedroom high-rise dwelling.
While it's all too easy to poke fun at the film's earnestness and clunky dramaturgy, one can't deny that it holds the audience in the palm of its hand throughout.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The under-5 set in particular should enjoy Pooh's goofy antics.
On a scene-to-scene basis though, Captain America is lumpy and formless.
A few rough patches aside, I found Midnight in Paris to be a delight
Handsomely mounted and packed with interesting historical details, Empire of Silver unfortunately falls short on providing emotionally rich drama
A solid, sturdy comic book movie that combines X2's showmanship with the first X-Men's strong narrative throughline.
It is at once both the movie I hoped it might be and also completely unlike anything I could have expected.
Although made in Belgium, Olivier Masset-Depasse's drama depicts a scenario that should resonate on these shores as well.
An extended trailer masquerading as a feature film
Forget that old computer game you may have played in middle school: Kelly Reichardt's fourth feature is a beautifully evocative portrait of life on the real Oregon Trail.
While Blank City's overall tone is celebratory, Danhier doesn't entirely shy away from some of the less admirable aspects of her subjects' lives.
Motion-capture animation takes a giant step backwards with this unappealing outer-space adventure.
The film draws you in with its formal rigor and measured storytelling.
movie_title: La princesse de Montpensier (The Princess of Montpensier) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The entire movie is about as superficial as your average commercial
movie_title: POM Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Too bad the film surrounding the fight scenes is there to be tolerated rather than fully enjoyed.
movie_title: Legend of the Fist: The Return of Chen Zhen (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A grounded, sometimes painfully honest look at a group of people dedicating themselves to a profession that the rest of the world doesn't completely understand.
Despite the provocative title, this Star Wars-themed documentary is less effective as a legal brief than as a portrait of contemporary fandom.
Rhymes with bore.
Bridesmaids moves with poise and confidence, making the hard business of earning honest laughs look easy.
After a strong first half, Everything Must Go ends up selling its leading man short.
What captured and mostly held my interest was the film's melancholic mood and its touching portrait of a man attempting to move beyond a great personal loss.
While entirely pleasant viewing, it's worth noting that Hey Boo isn't particularly distinguished filmmaking.
movie_title: Hey, Boo: Harper Lee and 'To Kill a Mockingbird' (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Although it tries to give the Pirates of the Caribbean franchise a fresh start, this lackluster fourth installment instead confirms that the series' charms have worn off.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Director Jennifer Yuh Nelson keeps the action swift and the tone light, but the movie lacks both the subtle grace notes and compelling characterizations that would make it a richer viewing experience.
As vampire movies go, it's a damn sight better than Twilight.
A potentially interesting premise is squandered by disappointing execution in this micro-budget indie comedy.
Another Earth ignores the fascinating sociological, political and scientific implications...and instead treats it as an extended metaphor in an aggravatingly melodramatic plot.
Thanks to the director's inquisitive camera and the sheer beauty of the setting, I fell under [the film's] spell early on and remained captivated throughout.
It's a shame that the characters that orbit the film's star are far more predictably written and performed.
It's not just low-energy -- at times the film barely seems to have a pulse.
Despite its many flaws, it's the most provocative and least predictable movie that Kevin Smith has made in years, at least since Dogma way back in 1999.
Once I stopped pining for the movie Moneyball might have been, I settled in and had a good time with what it was.
It's not even that the film is an unwatchable disaster -- it's just a big disappointment.
The filmmakers want to honor this man's achievements, but viewers will likely leave the theater uncertain as to what exactly it was that he accomplished.
Whatever laughs and tears the film wrings out of you do ultimately feel earned.
Like the final notes of an opera, the film lingers, inviting you back to explore its mysteries a second and even a third time.
A beautifully assured work of art that doubles as an up-to-the-minute portrait of the country's mood.
Moderately involving, but ultimately underwhelming...
Count me in as a reluctant unbeliever.
The Human Centipede II is ultimately too calculated and contrived a film to offer any real scares, but Harvey's performance is genuinely terrifying.
Another unique, challenging piece of work from one of the world's most consistently creative filmmakers.
Killing Bono's rise-and-fall arc is a little predictable, but the cast is spirited and U2 fans should get a kick out of the references to the band's early days.
If Footloose had to be remade, this is probably the best version we were likely to get.
Some of the [monster] attacks are well-staged, but because we're not at all invested in the characters' survival, there's little tension or sense of danger to keep us on the edge of our seats.
If the main reason you go to the movies is to be spun a good yarn, almost nobody does it better than Pedro Almodóvar.
In trying to send audiences out of the theater uplifted, Father of Invention instead leaves us sadly shaking our heads about how much better the movie could have been.

If it lacks the original's novelty value and sheer sense of surprise, it makes up for it with creative filmmaking, likeable (for once) characters, a healthy dash of humor and a couple of great scares.
Thoughtfully conceived and executed with clockwork precision.
This is an undeniably clumsy film, but a good heart beats inside its chest and that counts for something.
The rest of The Lion King doesn't measure up to its title sequence...[but] it's a more interesting movie than I remember it being.
Strands a good cast and some well-observed moments of social commentary in a movie that ultimately embraces the same fantasy it supposedly set out to critique.
movie_title: I Don't Know How She Does It (2011)

movie_review_blurb: While the new version mostly follows the original's narrative beat-for-beat, it feels strangely sanitized.

Like a cinematic version of Frankenstein's monster, this ensemble romantic dramedy is stitched together out of pieces of other, far better movies, and brought to unnatural life by an overqualified cast.
Perhaps one of the highest compliments I can pay Attack the Block is that it feels like a movie that might have played on a double bill with Gremlins back in the early '80s.
As an attempt to reflect The Way We Live Now, it falls short in a few key ways.
The film's relentless juvenilia grows wearisome after a while, especially when it becomes apparent that the filmmakers don't have any other comic tricks up their sleeves.
This is first and foremost Ansari's showcase and he nails each scene like he's been acting in movies for ages.
The stars are able to keep the tedium at bay for a little while.
One Day is such a cannily crafted tale of love and loss that you're always aware (and kind of hate) just how much it's manipulating you and yet get caught up in it anyway.
In its best moments, Don't Be Afraid of the Dark resembles a modern version of an original Grimm's fairy tale.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A waste of time, talent and resources on a movie that would feel more at home in the direct-to-DVD aisle of your local big box store than on a multiplex marquee.
Davis could play a role like Bunnie in her sleep, Mulroney often seems to be asleep and the rest of the overqualified supporting cast just appears relieved that their screentime is limited.
A remarkable you-are-there recreation of the past decade of American covert affairs.
First-time documentary filmmaker Nathan Christ paints a compelling, if somewhat diffuse, portrait of a city-to say nothing of an entire industry-in transition.
The word "gravitas" gets tossed around a lot, but Warrior has it in spades.
Contagion is an exceptionally well-crafted film, one that feels frighteningly realistic despite the movie star cast.
Offers some decent scares once you get past the somewhat labored set-up.
An entertaining, comprehensive look at a slender, but significant slice of pop culture history.
Midnight movie fans as well as graphic artists will appreciate the style of the picture, if not the substance... mainly because there's not much substance to be found at all.
While it covers familiar ground, it does so with a light touch.
The first fifteen minutes of Drive may be the best movie I've seen this year.
Much like her debut film, Miranda July's sophomore feature keeps dancing perilously close to the edge of terminal whimsy only to be yanked back by moments of stunning emotional truth.
The difficulty of the [central character's] predicament lends the movie considerable dramatic weight.
Bier's latest film-which just took home the Oscar for Best Foreign Language Film-is not the strongest example of her considerable talent.
A well-told sci-fi yarn.
The script careens wildly between comic moments that aren't funny and dramatic moments that are preposterous and banal.
A vivid portrait of a New York that's long since vanished.
David Fincher, Aaron Sorkin and a terrific ensemble of young actors reveal the (not quite) true story behind the Facebook phenomenon.
A modest pleasure.
movie_title: Cameraman: The Life And Work Of Jack Cardiff (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Scorsese offers a stirring analysis of Kazan's artistry while also describing in heartfelt terms how these stories affected him as a nascent movie lover.
This enjoyable if uneven anthology documentary manages to break even, with two strong segments making up for two weaker ones.
A bland horse tale enlivened only by Diane Lane's committed star turn and a wily supporting performance by John Malkovich.
Out of the nine shorts included here, only four prove to be particularly memorable and only one of that group is a perfect marriage of form and content.
Jack Goes Boating doesn't exactly herald the arrival of a major new filmmaking talent, but it does act as a modestly entertaining showcase for a group of versatile performers.
Overall, Tibet in Song provides an impassioned, yet relatively clear-eyed account of its director's turbulent homecoming.
The actors succeed at portraying a couple whose bond is strong enough to not require words.
It's impressive that documentarian Simone Bitton manages to remain neutral for so much of her film.

There's certainly something charming about the camaraderie this gang of idiots shares, as well as their general inclusiveness. It doesn't matter if you're short, fat or ugly-if you're willing to take a tee ball to the nads, you too can be a Jackass.
The finished product so often feels like an early draft of a movie that's in dire need of further revision.
The fickleness and absurdity of life in L.A.'s entertainment industry has been skewered more effectively in a number of other movies.
In classic fashion, Paranormal Activity 2 repeats its predecessor on a slightly bigger scale to considerably lesser effect.
This low-budget creature feature creates a rich sci-fi universe but fails to populate it with compelling characters.
There's simply no urgency to the proceedings.
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Thank goodness we still have Frederick Wiseman around to show us how old-school cinema verite is done.
A cult movie is born with the release of Gasper Noé's dazzling and demented tour-de-force.
The film is shapeless in a way that suggests Affleck and his editing team is making it up entirely out of odds and ends.
Catfish is an example of documentary filmmakers shaping reality to suit their own storytelling needs.
The overall effect is almost hypnotic.
An entertaining and lively portrait of a performer whose contribution to comedy is often, and probably unfairly, overlooked
movie_title: Joan Rivers: A Piece Of Work (2010)

movie_review_blurb: An intriguing comic-book hero is left stranded in a half-baked film adaptation that bears the marks of severe post-production tinkering.
The intelligence, wit, emotion and sheer care that the studio brings to this production is more than enough to make up for the few instances where its ambition outstrips its execution.
Overall, Knight and Day succeeds in its modest aspiration to provide light, fun summer entertainment.
A well-crafted, solidly entertaining meat-and-potatoes action movie that gives the titular creatures their best showcase since the original Predator.
A generally okay kiddie picture that lacks the emotional power Toy Story 3 or the witty hijinks of How to Train Your Dragon, but provides some solid laughs for the 8-and-under crowd.
A would-be thriller that suffers from glacial pacing, choppy editing, bland direction and a distinct lack of thrills.
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: There's a lot of money onscreen in Jerry Bruckheimer's latest family-friendly blockbuster, but it can't hide the two-bit story and script.
The last act makes up for a lot of the movie's earlier flaws, as Cholodenko nudges the material beyond the somewhat generic comedy of the first half into rawer, more compelling emotional territory.
Inception is often thrilling to watch, but there's something hollow at its center.
Salt seems aware of its own silliness, but that's actually part of the problem%u2014the movie thinks it's more fun than it actually is.
A clockwork French farce becomes a rambling Hollywood buddy comedy that's alternately hilarious and cringe-inducing.
For its sheer sense of spectacle alone, Scott Pilgrim is a treat.
Neil Marshall reaffirms his status as a contemporary "King of the B's" with another straight-up genre flick that's low on budget but high on fun.
Silliness reigns in Alexandre Aja's agreeably cartoonish remake of the '70s exploitation picture.
Anton Corbijn's plodding attempt at a '60s Euro-thriller makes for a scenic travelogue but offers little in the way of drama or intrigue.
Robert Rodriguez's unofficial sequel to his half of Grindhouse is a lot like its predecessor--gory, funny and, in the end, somewhat disappointing.
The film's tepid songs are emblematic of its tepid characterizations.
Too bad that Phillips and his team of screenwriters don't take full advantage of the stars' unique chemistry.
Four Lions isn't just the funniest movie of the year-it's also one of the smartest.
Trim and focused without an ounce of narrative fat, 127 Hours is a thrillingly immersive viewing experience.
An eminently watchable, but curiously muted dramatization of the Valerie Plame affair.
It's a visually arresting adventure, but it arrives at its final destination with little dramatic resonance.
A film that speeds through a dizzying array of silly plotlines in its 86 rambunctious minutes.
As factory-assembled rom-coms go, No Strings Attached isn't as dire as last year's Killers (also starring Kutcher) or 2009's Bride Wars.
The Other Woman firmly plants its feet and slaps you across the face until it wrests that precious, precious salt water from your eyes.
A film of modest ambition that mostly lives up to the low bar it sets for itself.
Less interesting as a feature-length movie than it is as a filmmaking and distribution experiment
An inoffensive but entirely unmemorable kiddie version of the Bard's classic romance.
This thoughtful-if at times clumsy-film is the latest salvo in the ongoing debate over the increased power of the pharmaceutical industry.

In its low-key way, Putty Hill effectively shows how tragedy can unite young people that are otherwise disconnected from their community. Watching it though, I too often felt disconnected from the movie.
It may not be the second coming of There's Something About Mary, but the Farrelly Brothers' latest offers a number of hearty laughs and good performances to boot.
One of my favorites of this young year and among the most unique features I've seen from an American animation house in recent memory.
Perhaps the best way to experience Uncle Boonmee or really any Weerasethakul film is to let his odd vision of the world sweep over you and not sweat the details too much.
movie_title: Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall His Past Lives (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A strong ensemble-with one notable exception-is the main attraction of this otherwise slight and unmemorable period comedy.
This particular screen version never generates a lot of heat or intrigue
Too ramshackle and sloppy to leave much of a lasting impression.
A comprehensive look at the creation and afterlife of a significant work of art.
While not as cohesive as Simon Pegg and Nick Frost's previous genre riffs, this rambling alien road comedy has its own loose, enjoyable vibe.
Gruesome in the moment, but your memory of it is easily wiped clean.

I'm Dangerous with Love isn't particularly compelling or trustworthy as a character portrait.
If only the movie's cast of ordinary working stiffs weren't quite so bland and, frankly, dull.

Jonathan Swift's witty 18th-century satire becomes a witless 21st-century star vehicle for Jack Black and his by-now stale shtick.
Solid but unexceptional high-concept action programmer from Tony Scott, who has delivered bigger thrills in previous pictures.
Although it contributes some intriguing ideas to the ongoing global warming discussion, this potentially controversial documentary remains too vague on several key issues.
The Harry Potter series draws to a close with the action-packed but dramatically clunky first half of the two-part finale.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Don't be completely deceived by the film's light touch; Disco and Atomic War still makes a number of salient points.
movie_title: Disco and Atomic War (Disko ja tuumasoda) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The cast handles the material adequately enough, but writer/director Joseph Infantolino doesn't provide them with anything they (and we) haven't seen played out before.
Burlesque gets by for a little while on its spirit and general eagerness to entertain....But it quickly becomes clear that Antin has miscalculated in some major ways.
The [filmmaking] process obviously helped Colvard and his sisters heal in some small way and may have the same effect on certain viewers as well.
Feels as factory-assembled as one of the Ford cars glimpsed in the movie.
The King's Speech has been crafted to serve as an actors' showcase first and foremost and Firth and Rush don't disappoint.
A film that's not easy to shake.
Edward Zwick successfully cloaks his critique of Big Pharma in the guise of a funny, sexy romantic comedy...until the third-act doldrums set in, that is.
Whatever missteps the films makes along the way are almost completely made up for by its terrific third act.
The magic is over, folks. The third and likely final entry in the Narnia franchise is a listless, plodding bore.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader (2010)

movie_review_blurb: While it's not a total knockout, The Fighter wins on points thanks to a strong ensemble cast and director David O. Russell's playful spirit behind the camera.
The unusual partnership between two French filmmakers-Sylvain Chomet and the late Jacques Tati-results in a beautiful, touching feat of movie magic.
Another animated relic is dusted off for an underwhelming and unnecessary live-action outing.
The long-awaited sequel to the 1982 cult favorite retains the original's visual splendor, but not its endearingly geeky spirit.
While the final scenes strike a false note, so much of Somewhere rings true.
The Coen Brothers hit the bull's-eye with this captivating western where the good guys fight with words first and guns second.
While it sports a few spare parts that don't quite click, this souped-up superhero vehicle runs smoothly enough thanks to a savvy sense of humor and the charisma of its central crime-fighting duo.
A modest, mostly engaging behind-the-scenes documentary that nevertheless winds up feeling somehow incomplete.
The Debt has one of the worst endings to an otherwise well-crafted thriller in recent memory.
The Rum Diary is too timid...recounting Thompson's words, but never really providing us with any insight into his mind.
Perhaps the best way to summarize the movie is to borrow the final line from one of the comics that inspired it: The Dark Knight Rises is a good film. Good enough.
You'll be lucky to remember anything about this new one when you wake up the morning after seeing it.
Mostly The Babymakers coasts lazily along on the likability of the cast and the occasional amusing moment.
Jones and Samberg are appealing and believable as a couple that aren't sure how to move on from what's been the defining relationship of their lives.
Game Change might have felt fresh had it hit the airwaves in 2010, but in 2012 it's just more of the same.
It's a film of modest ambitions, but it mostly achieves them and does so in an entertaining, emotionally honest fashion to boot.
There are certainly laughs to be had here, but maybe Klown was more effective (and funnier) in thirty-minute doses on TV than dragged out to feature length.
